connector.description: Socket level networking using TCP or UDP with the Netty 4.x.

camel.source.path.protocol.name: camel.source.path.protocol
camel.source.path.protocol.description: The protocol to use which can be tcp or udp. One of: [tcp] [udp]

camel.source.path.host.name: camel.source.path.host
camel.source.path.host.description: The hostname. For the consumer the hostname is localhost or 0.0.0.0. For the producer the hostname is the remote host to connect to

camel.source.endpoint.disconnect.name: camel.source.endpoint.disconnect
camel.source.endpoint.disconnect.description: Whether or not to disconnect(close) from Netty Channel right after use. Can be used for both consumer and producer.

camel.source.endpoint.keepAlive.name: camel.source.endpoint.keepAlive
camel.source.endpoint.keepAlive.description: Setting to ensure socket is not closed due to inactivity

camel.source.endpoint.reuseChannel.name: camel.source.endpoint.reuseChannel
camel.source.endpoint.reuseChannel.description: This option allows producers and consumers (in client mode) to reuse the same Netty Channel for the lifecycle of processing the Exchange. This is useful if you need to call a server multiple times in a Camel route and want to use the same network connection. When using this, the channel is not returned to the connection pool until the Exchange is done; or disconnected if the disconnect option is set to true. The reused Channel is stored on the Exchange as an exchange property with the key NettyConstants#NETTY_CHANNEL which allows you to obtain the channel during routing and use it as well.

camel.source.endpoint.sync.name: camel.source.endpoint.sync
camel.source.endpoint.sync.description: Setting to set endpoint as one-way or request-response

camel.source.endpoint.tcpNoDelay.name: camel.source.endpoint.tcpNoDelay
camel.source.endpoint.tcpNoDelay.description: Setting to improve TCP protocol performance

camel.source.endpoint.bridgeErrorHandler.name: camel.source.endpoint.bridgeErrorHandler
camel.source.endpoint.bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.

camel.source.endpoint.broadcast.name: camel.source.endpoint.broadcast
camel.source.endpoint.broadcast.description: Setting to choose Multicast over UDP

camel.source.endpoint.clientMode.name: camel.source.endpoint.clientMode
camel.source.endpoint.clientMode.description: If the clientMode is true, netty consumer will connect the address as a TCP client.

camel.source.endpoint.reconnect.name: camel.source.endpoint.reconnect
camel.source.endpoint.reconnect.description: Used only in clientMode in consumer, the consumer will attempt to reconnect on disconnection if this is enabled

camel.source.endpoint.reconnectInterval.name: camel.source.endpoint.reconnectInterval
camel.source.endpoint.reconnectInterval.description: Used if reconnect and clientMode is enabled. The interval in milli seconds to attempt reconnection

camel.source.endpoint.backlog.name: camel.source.endpoint.backlog
camel.source.endpoint.backlog.description: Allows to configure a backlog for netty consumer (server). Note the backlog is just a best effort depending on the OS. Setting this option to a value such as 200, 500 or 1000, tells the TCP stack how long the accept queue can be If this option is not configured, then the backlog depends on OS setting.

camel.source.endpoint.bossCount.name: camel.source.endpoint.bossCount
camel.source.endpoint.bossCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default bossCount parameter from Netty, which is 1. User can use this option to override the default bossCount from Netty

camel.source.endpoint.bossGroup.name: camel.source.endpoint.bossGroup
camel.source.endpoint.bossGroup.description: Set the BossGroup which could be used for handling the new connection of the server side across the NettyEndpoint

camel.source.endpoint.disconnectOnNoRepl.name: camel.source.endpoint.disconnectOnNoReply
camel.source.endpoint.disconnectOnNoRepl.description: If sync is enabled then this option dictates NettyConsumer if it should disconnect where there is no reply to send back.

camel.source.endpoint.exceptionHandler.name: camel.source.endpoint.exceptionHandler
camel.source.endpoint.exceptionHandler.description: To let the consumer use a custom ExceptionHandler. Notice if the option bridgeErrorHandler is enabled then this option is not in use. By default the consumer will deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.

camel.source.endpoint.exchangePattern.name: camel.source.endpoint.exchangePattern
camel.source.endpoint.exchangePattern.description: Sets the exchange pattern when the consumer creates an exchange. One of: [InOnly] [InOut] [InOptionalOut]

camel.source.endpoint.networkInterface.name: camel.source.endpoint.networkInterface
camel.source.endpoint.networkInterface.description: When using UDP then this option can be used to specify a network interface by its name, such as eth0 to join a multicast group.

camel.source.endpoint.noReplyLogLevel.name: camel.source.endpoint.noReplyLogLevel
camel.source.endpoint.noReplyLogLevel.description: If sync is enabled this option dictates NettyConsumer which logging level to use when logging a there is no reply to send back. One of: [TRACE] [DEBUG] [INFO] [WARN] [ERROR] [OFF]

camel.source.endpoint.serverClosedChanne.name: camel.source.endpoint.serverClosedChannelExceptionCaughtLogLevel
camel.source.endpoint.serverClosedChanne.description: If the server (NettyConsumer) catches an java.nio.channels.ClosedChannelException then its logged using this logging level. This is used to avoid logging the closed channel exceptions, as clients can disconnect abruptly and then cause a flood of closed exceptions in the Netty server. One of: [TRACE] [DEBUG] [INFO] [WARN] [ERROR] [OFF]

camel.source.endpoint.serverExceptionCau.name: camel.source.endpoint.serverExceptionCaughtLogLevel
camel.source.endpoint.serverExceptionCau.description: If the server (NettyConsumer) catches an exception then its logged using this logging level. One of: [TRACE] [DEBUG] [INFO] [WARN] [ERROR] [OFF]

camel.source.endpoint.usingExecutorServi.name: camel.source.endpoint.usingExecutorService
camel.source.endpoint.usingExecutorServi.description: Whether to use ordered thread pool, to ensure events are processed orderly on the same channel.

camel.source.endpoint.allowSerializedHea.name: camel.source.endpoint.allowSerializedHeaders
camel.source.endpoint.allowSerializedHea.description: Only used for TCP when transferExchange is true. When set to true, serializable objects in headers and properties will be added to the exchange. Otherwise Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.

camel.source.endpoint.nativeTransport.name: camel.source.endpoint.nativeTransport
camel.source.endpoint.nativeTransport.description: Whether to use native transport instead of NIO. Native transport takes advantage of the host operating system and is only supported on some platforms. You need to add the netty JAR for the host operating system you are using. See more details at: http://netty.io/wiki/native-transports.html

camel.source.endpoint.options.name: camel.source.endpoint.options
camel.source.endpoint.options.description: Allows to configure additional netty options using option. as prefix. For example option.child.keepAlive=false to set the netty option child.keepAlive=false. See the Netty documentation for possible options that can be used.

camel.source.endpoint.receiveBufferSize.name: camel.source.endpoint.receiveBufferSize
camel.source.endpoint.receiveBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during inbound communication. Size is bytes.

camel.source.endpoint.receiveBufferSizeP.name: camel.source.endpoint.receiveBufferSizePredictor
camel.source.endpoint.receiveBufferSizeP.description: Configures the buffer size predictor. See details at Jetty documentation and this mail thread.

camel.source.endpoint.sendBufferSize.name: camel.source.endpoint.sendBufferSize
camel.source.endpoint.sendBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during outbound communication. Size is bytes.

camel.source.endpoint.synchronous.name: camel.source.endpoint.synchronous
camel.source.endpoint.synchronous.description: Sets whether synchronous processing should be strictly used, or Camel is allowed to use asynchronous processing (if supported).

camel.source.endpoint.transferExchange.name: camel.source.endpoint.transferExchange
camel.source.endpoint.transferExchange.description: Only used for TCP. You can transfer the exchange over the wire instead of just the body. The following fields are transferred: In body, Out body, fault body, In headers, Out headers, fault headers, exchange properties, exchange exception. This requires that the objects are serializable. Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.

camel.source.endpoint.udpByteArrayCodec.name: camel.source.endpoint.udpByteArrayCodec
camel.source.endpoint.udpByteArrayCodec.description: For UDP only. If enabled the using byte array codec instead of Java serialization protocol.

camel.source.endpoint.workerCount.name: camel.source.endpoint.workerCount
camel.source.endpoint.workerCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default workerCount parameter from Netty (which is cpu_core_threads x 2). User can use this option to override the default workerCount from Netty.

camel.source.endpoint.workerGroup.name: camel.source.endpoint.workerGroup
camel.source.endpoint.workerGroup.description: To use a explicit EventLoopGroup as the boss thread pool. For example to share a thread pool with multiple consumers or producers. By default each consumer or producer has their own worker pool with 2 x cpu count core threads.

camel.source.endpoint.allowDefaultCodec.name: camel.source.endpoint.allowDefaultCodec
camel.source.endpoint.allowDefaultCodec.description: The netty component installs a default codec if both, encoder/decoder is null and textline is false. Setting allowDefaultCodec to false prevents the netty component from installing a default codec as the first element in the filter chain.

camel.source.endpoint.autoAppendDelimite.name: camel.source.endpoint.autoAppendDelimiter
camel.source.endpoint.autoAppendDelimite.description: Whether or not to auto append missing end delimiter when sending using the textline codec.

camel.source.endpoint.decoderMaxLineLeng.name: camel.source.endpoint.decoderMaxLineLength
camel.source.endpoint.decoderMaxLineLeng.description: The max line length to use for the textline codec.

camel.source.endpoint.decoders.name: camel.source.endpoint.decoders
camel.source.endpoint.decoders.description: A list of decoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.

camel.source.endpoint.delimiter.name: camel.source.endpoint.delimiter
camel.source.endpoint.delimiter.description: The delimiter to use for the textline codec. Possible values are LINE and NULL. One of: [LINE] [NULL]

camel.source.endpoint.encoders.name: camel.source.endpoint.encoders
camel.source.endpoint.encoders.description: A list of encoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.

camel.source.endpoint.encoding.name: camel.source.endpoint.encoding
camel.source.endpoint.encoding.description: The encoding (a charset name) to use for the textline codec. If not provided, Camel will use the JVM default Charset.

camel.source.endpoint.textline.name: camel.source.endpoint.textline
camel.source.endpoint.textline.description: Only used for TCP. If no codec is specified, you can use this flag to indicate a text line based codec; if not specified or the value is false, then Object Serialization is assumed over TCP - however only Strings are allowed to be serialized by default.

camel.source.endpoint.enabledProtocols.name: camel.source.endpoint.enabledProtocols
camel.source.endpoint.enabledProtocols.description: Which protocols to enable when using SSL

camel.source.endpoint.keyStoreFile.name: camel.source.endpoint.keyStoreFile
camel.source.endpoint.keyStoreFile.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption

camel.source.endpoint.keyStoreFormat.name: camel.source.endpoint.keyStoreFormat
camel.source.endpoint.keyStoreFormat.description: Keystore format to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to JKS if not set

camel.source.endpoint.keyStoreResource.name: camel.source.endpoint.keyStoreResource
camel.source.endpoint.keyStoreResource.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.

camel.source.endpoint.needClientAuth.name: camel.source.endpoint.needClientAuth
camel.source.endpoint.needClientAuth.description: Configures whether the server needs client authentication when using SSL.

camel.source.endpoint.passphrase.name: camel.source.endpoint.passphrase
camel.source.endpoint.passphrase.description: Password setting to use in order to encrypt/decrypt payloads sent using SSH

camel.source.endpoint.securityProvider.name: camel.source.endpoint.securityProvider
camel.source.endpoint.securityProvider.description: Security provider to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to SunX509 if not set.

camel.source.endpoint.ssl.name: camel.source.endpoint.ssl
camel.source.endpoint.ssl.description: Setting to specify whether SSL encryption is applied to this endpoint

camel.source.endpoint.sslClientCertHeade.name: camel.source.endpoint.sslClientCertHeaders
camel.source.endpoint.sslClientCertHeade.description: When enabled and in SSL mode, then the Netty consumer will enrich the Camel Message with headers having information about the client certificate such as subject name, issuer name, serial number, and the valid date range.

camel.source.endpoint.sslHandler.name: camel.source.endpoint.sslHandler
camel.source.endpoint.sslHandler.description: Reference to a class that could be used to return an SSL Handler

camel.source.endpoint.trustStoreFile.name: camel.source.endpoint.trustStoreFile
camel.source.endpoint.trustStoreFile.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption

camel.source.endpoint.trustStoreResource.name: camel.source.endpoint.trustStoreResource
camel.source.endpoint.trustStoreResource.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.

camel.component.netty.configuration.name: camel.component.netty.configuration
camel.component.netty.configuration.description: To use the NettyConfiguration as configuration when creating endpoints.

camel.component.netty.disconnect.name: camel.component.netty.disconnect
camel.component.netty.disconnect.description: Whether or not to disconnect(close) from Netty Channel right after use. Can be used for both consumer and producer.

camel.component.netty.keepAlive.name: camel.component.netty.keepAlive
camel.component.netty.keepAlive.description: Setting to ensure socket is not closed due to inactivity

camel.component.netty.reuseChannel.name: camel.component.netty.reuseChannel
camel.component.netty.reuseChannel.description: This option allows producers and consumers (in client mode) to reuse the same Netty Channel for the lifecycle of processing the Exchange. This is useful if you need to call a server multiple times in a Camel route and want to use the same network connection. When using this, the channel is not returned to the connection pool until the Exchange is done; or disconnected if the disconnect option is set to true. The reused Channel is stored on the Exchange as an exchange property with the key NettyConstants#NETTY_CHANNEL which allows you to obtain the channel during routing and use it as well.

camel.component.netty.sync.name: camel.component.netty.sync
camel.component.netty.sync.description: Setting to set endpoint as one-way or request-response

camel.component.netty.tcpNoDelay.name: camel.component.netty.tcpNoDelay
camel.component.netty.tcpNoDelay.description: Setting to improve TCP protocol performance

camel.component.netty.bridgeErrorHandler.name: camel.component.netty.bridgeErrorHandler
camel.component.netty.bridgeErrorHandler.description: Allows for bridging the consumer to the Camel routing Error Handler, which mean any exceptions occurred while the consumer is trying to pickup incoming messages, or the likes, will now be processed as a message and handled by the routing Error Handler. By default the consumer will use the org.apache.camel.spi.ExceptionHandler to deal with exceptions, that will be logged at WARN or ERROR level and ignored.

camel.component.netty.broadcast.name: camel.component.netty.broadcast
camel.component.netty.broadcast.description: Setting to choose Multicast over UDP

camel.component.netty.clientMode.name: camel.component.netty.clientMode
camel.component.netty.clientMode.description: If the clientMode is true, netty consumer will connect the address as a TCP client.

camel.component.netty.reconnect.name: camel.component.netty.reconnect
camel.component.netty.reconnect.description: Used only in clientMode in consumer, the consumer will attempt to reconnect on disconnection if this is enabled

camel.component.netty.reconnectInterval.name: camel.component.netty.reconnectInterval
camel.component.netty.reconnectInterval.description: Used if reconnect and clientMode is enabled. The interval in milli seconds to attempt reconnection

camel.component.netty.backlog.name: camel.component.netty.backlog
camel.component.netty.backlog.description: Allows to configure a backlog for netty consumer (server). Note the backlog is just a best effort depending on the OS. Setting this option to a value such as 200, 500 or 1000, tells the TCP stack how long the accept queue can be If this option is not configured, then the backlog depends on OS setting.

camel.component.netty.bossCount.name: camel.component.netty.bossCount
camel.component.netty.bossCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default bossCount parameter from Netty, which is 1. User can use this option to override the default bossCount from Netty

camel.component.netty.bossGroup.name: camel.component.netty.bossGroup
camel.component.netty.bossGroup.description: Set the BossGroup which could be used for handling the new connection of the server side across the NettyEndpoint

camel.component.netty.disconnectOnNoRepl.name: camel.component.netty.disconnectOnNoReply
camel.component.netty.disconnectOnNoRepl.description: If sync is enabled then this option dictates NettyConsumer if it should disconnect where there is no reply to send back.

camel.component.netty.maximumPoolSize.name: camel.component.netty.maximumPoolSize
camel.component.netty.maximumPoolSize.description: Sets a maximum thread pool size for the netty consumer ordered thread pool. The default size is 2 x cpu_core plus 1. Setting this value to eg 10 will then use 10 threads unless 2 x cpu_core plus 1 is a higher value, which then will override and be used. For example if there are 8 cores, then the consumer thread pool will be 17. This thread pool is used to route messages received from Netty by Camel. We use a separate thread pool to ensure ordering of messages and also in case some messages will block, then nettys worker threads (event loop) wont be affected.

camel.component.netty.networkInterface.name: camel.component.netty.networkInterface
camel.component.netty.networkInterface.description: When using UDP then this option can be used to specify a network interface by its name, such as eth0 to join a multicast group.

camel.component.netty.noReplyLogLevel.name: camel.component.netty.noReplyLogLevel
camel.component.netty.noReplyLogLevel.description: If sync is enabled this option dictates NettyConsumer which logging level to use when logging a there is no reply to send back. One of: [TRACE] [DEBUG] [INFO] [WARN] [ERROR] [OFF]

camel.component.netty.serverClosedChanne.name: camel.component.netty.serverClosedChannelExceptionCaughtLogLevel
camel.component.netty.serverClosedChanne.description: If the server (NettyConsumer) catches an java.nio.channels.ClosedChannelException then its logged using this logging level. This is used to avoid logging the closed channel exceptions, as clients can disconnect abruptly and then cause a flood of closed exceptions in the Netty server. One of: [TRACE] [DEBUG] [INFO] [WARN] [ERROR] [OFF]

camel.component.netty.serverExceptionCau.name: camel.component.netty.serverExceptionCaughtLogLevel
camel.component.netty.serverExceptionCau.description: If the server (NettyConsumer) catches an exception then its logged using this logging level. One of: [TRACE] [DEBUG] [INFO] [WARN] [ERROR] [OFF]

camel.component.netty.usingExecutorServi.name: camel.component.netty.usingExecutorService
camel.component.netty.usingExecutorServi.description: Whether to use ordered thread pool, to ensure events are processed orderly on the same channel.

camel.component.netty.allowSerializedHea.name: camel.component.netty.allowSerializedHeaders
camel.component.netty.allowSerializedHea.description: Only used for TCP when transferExchange is true. When set to true, serializable objects in headers and properties will be added to the exchange. Otherwise Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.

camel.component.netty.autowiredEnabled.name: camel.component.netty.autowiredEnabled
camel.component.netty.autowiredEnabled.description: Whether autowiring is enabled. This is used for automatic autowiring options (the option must be marked as autowired) by looking up in the registry to find if there is a single instance of matching type, which then gets configured on the component. This can be used for automatic configuring JDBC data sources, JMS connection factories, AWS Clients, etc.

camel.component.netty.nativeTransport.name: camel.component.netty.nativeTransport
camel.component.netty.nativeTransport.description: Whether to use native transport instead of NIO. Native transport takes advantage of the host operating system and is only supported on some platforms. You need to add the netty JAR for the host operating system you are using. See more details at: http://netty.io/wiki/native-transports.html

camel.component.netty.options.name: camel.component.netty.options
camel.component.netty.options.description: Allows to configure additional netty options using option. as prefix. For example option.child.keepAlive=false to set the netty option child.keepAlive=false. See the Netty documentation for possible options that can be used.

camel.component.netty.receiveBufferSize.name: camel.component.netty.receiveBufferSize
camel.component.netty.receiveBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during inbound communication. Size is bytes.

camel.component.netty.receiveBufferSizeP.name: camel.component.netty.receiveBufferSizePredictor
camel.component.netty.receiveBufferSizeP.description: Configures the buffer size predictor. See details at Jetty documentation and this mail thread.

camel.component.netty.sendBufferSize.name: camel.component.netty.sendBufferSize
camel.component.netty.sendBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during outbound communication. Size is bytes.

camel.component.netty.transferExchange.name: camel.component.netty.transferExchange
camel.component.netty.transferExchange.description: Only used for TCP. You can transfer the exchange over the wire instead of just the body. The following fields are transferred: In body, Out body, fault body, In headers, Out headers, fault headers, exchange properties, exchange exception. This requires that the objects are serializable. Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.

camel.component.netty.udpByteArrayCodec.name: camel.component.netty.udpByteArrayCodec
camel.component.netty.udpByteArrayCodec.description: For UDP only. If enabled the using byte array codec instead of Java serialization protocol.

camel.component.netty.workerCount.name: camel.component.netty.workerCount
camel.component.netty.workerCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default workerCount parameter from Netty (which is cpu_core_threads x 2). User can use this option to override the default workerCount from Netty.

camel.component.netty.workerGroup.name: camel.component.netty.workerGroup
camel.component.netty.workerGroup.description: To use a explicit EventLoopGroup as the boss thread pool. For example to share a thread pool with multiple consumers or producers. By default each consumer or producer has their own worker pool with 2 x cpu count core threads.

camel.component.netty.allowDefaultCodec.name: camel.component.netty.allowDefaultCodec
camel.component.netty.allowDefaultCodec.description: The netty component installs a default codec if both, encoder/decoder is null and textline is false. Setting allowDefaultCodec to false prevents the netty component from installing a default codec as the first element in the filter chain.

camel.component.netty.autoAppendDelimite.name: camel.component.netty.autoAppendDelimiter
camel.component.netty.autoAppendDelimite.description: Whether or not to auto append missing end delimiter when sending using the textline codec.

camel.component.netty.decoderMaxLineLeng.name: camel.component.netty.decoderMaxLineLength
camel.component.netty.decoderMaxLineLeng.description: The max line length to use for the textline codec.

camel.component.netty.decoders.name: camel.component.netty.decoders
camel.component.netty.decoders.description: A list of decoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.

camel.component.netty.delimiter.name: camel.component.netty.delimiter
camel.component.netty.delimiter.description: The delimiter to use for the textline codec. Possible values are LINE and NULL. One of: [LINE] [NULL]

camel.component.netty.encoders.name: camel.component.netty.encoders
camel.component.netty.encoders.description: A list of encoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.

camel.component.netty.encoding.name: camel.component.netty.encoding
camel.component.netty.encoding.description: The encoding (a charset name) to use for the textline codec. If not provided, Camel will use the JVM default Charset.

camel.component.netty.textline.name: camel.component.netty.textline
camel.component.netty.textline.description: Only used for TCP. If no codec is specified, you can use this flag to indicate a text line based codec; if not specified or the value is false, then Object Serialization is assumed over TCP - however only Strings are allowed to be serialized by default.

camel.component.netty.enabledProtocols.name: camel.component.netty.enabledProtocols
camel.component.netty.enabledProtocols.description: Which protocols to enable when using SSL

camel.component.netty.keyStoreFile.name: camel.component.netty.keyStoreFile
camel.component.netty.keyStoreFile.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption

camel.component.netty.keyStoreFormat.name: camel.component.netty.keyStoreFormat
camel.component.netty.keyStoreFormat.description: Keystore format to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to JKS if not set

camel.component.netty.keyStoreResource.name: camel.component.netty.keyStoreResource
camel.component.netty.keyStoreResource.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.

camel.component.netty.needClientAuth.name: camel.component.netty.needClientAuth
camel.component.netty.needClientAuth.description: Configures whether the server needs client authentication when using SSL.

camel.component.netty.passphrase.name: camel.component.netty.passphrase
camel.component.netty.passphrase.description: Password setting to use in order to encrypt/decrypt payloads sent using SSH

camel.component.netty.securityProvider.name: camel.component.netty.securityProvider
camel.component.netty.securityProvider.description: Security provider to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to SunX509 if not set.

camel.component.netty.ssl.name: camel.component.netty.ssl
camel.component.netty.ssl.description: Setting to specify whether SSL encryption is applied to this endpoint

camel.component.netty.sslClientCertHeade.name: camel.component.netty.sslClientCertHeaders
camel.component.netty.sslClientCertHeade.description: When enabled and in SSL mode, then the Netty consumer will enrich the Camel Message with headers having information about the client certificate such as subject name, issuer name, serial number, and the valid date range.

camel.component.netty.sslHandler.name: camel.component.netty.sslHandler
camel.component.netty.sslHandler.description: Reference to a class that could be used to return an SSL Handler

camel.component.netty.trustStoreFile.name: camel.component.netty.trustStoreFile
camel.component.netty.trustStoreFile.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption

camel.component.netty.trustStoreResource.name: camel.component.netty.trustStoreResource
camel.component.netty.trustStoreResource.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.

camel.component.netty.useGlobalSslContex.name: camel.component.netty.useGlobalSslContextParameters
camel.component.netty.useGlobalSslContex.description: Enable usage of global SSL context parameters.
